sections.title: Components of a Financial Plan
sections.content: A comprehensive financial plan includes assessment of your current situation, goal setting, strategy development, and ongoing monitoring. It covers budgeting, debt management, investment planning, insurance, estate planning, and tax strategies. The plan should be written, specific, and reviewed regularly.

points.title: Current Financial Position
points.description: Net worth statement showing assets, liabilities, income, and expenses.

points.title: Goals and Objectives
points.description: Specific, measurable financial goals with timelines and priorities.

points.title: Risk Assessment
points.description: Evaluation of financial risks and appropriate insurance coverage.

sections.title: Financial Planning is Iterative
sections.content: Your financial plan isn't set in stone. As your life circumstances change, your plan should evolve to reflect new goals, income levels, and market conditions.

sections.title: Setting SMART Financial Goals
sections.content: SMART goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. Instead of 'save more money,' set 'save $10,000 for emergency fund by December 31st.' Break large goals into smaller milestones and celebrate progress along the way.

sections.title: Create Your Financial Plan
steps: Calculate your current net worth (assets minus liabilities)
Analyze your cash flow (income minus expenses) for the past 3-6 months
Set 3-5 specific financial goals with deadlines
Create an action plan with specific steps for each goal

sections.title: Start with What You Can Control
sections.content: Focus first on areas where you have direct control, like budgeting and debt reduction, before moving to areas with more uncertainty like investment returns.
